about hibernation and swap -- if your system actually uses the swap space while running you will need a bigger amount for hibernation

well, yes and no... i mean, it's possible, but it's also possible that the system is just swapping out applications' memory to make space for file cache, in which case it'll just do away with the file cache when you shutdown
an unlikely enough even that i wouldn't bother considering it when assigning swap, in any case
good point (1) -- but I'd still advocate swap = ram *1.5 or so (especially on notebooks where hibernating may occour at the worst time possible

if we're speaking in the league of 4 or 8 gigs as we are, i really believe that makes no sense. if you're using swap for any other reason than freeing up memory for file cache, then it means your system has already slowed to a halt already
if you want to cater for the unlikely and mostly useless events, on the other hand, then you need infinite memory ;)
